Detailed Description

The CQueue class wraps a native FreeRTOS queue handle (xQueueHandle). To create a queue instance an object of this class and then call its CQueue::Create method like showed in the following sample: 

 CQueue g_aQueue // global task declaration.

 void taskControlFunc(void *pParams)
 {
       unsigned char *Message;
       g_aQueue.Create(nQueueSize, sizeof(queueItemT));

       for (;;) {
              g_aQueue.Receive(&Message, portMAX_DELAY ) != pdTRUE)
              // do something
 }

See the CLcdTask for an example.

See also:
queue documentation in the FreeRTOS web site.
Date:
Jul 12, 2010
Author:
Stefano Oliveri (STF12.net) E-Mail: software@stf12.net

Definition at line 43 of file CQueue.h.

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

CQueue::CQueue ( )

The default constructor. It initializes the object without attaching it to a native FreeRTOS handle. Call the Create method to allocate a queue handle and attach it to the object.

CQueue.cpp

void CQueue::Attach ( xGenericHandle  handle) [virtual]

Attach the object to a given FreeRTOS handle. A previous attached handle is deleted and its resource are freed.

Parameters:
handlespecifies a native FreeRTOS handle.

Implements IFreeRTOSObj.

xGenericHandle CQueue::Detach ( ) [inline, virtual]

Usually a FreeRTOS handle is disposed and his resource freed when the attached object is deleted. Call this method to keep the handle alive.

Returns:
the native FreeRTOS handle. This handle is valid after the object is disposed.

Implements IFreeRTOSObj.

Definition at line 231 of file CQueue.h.

bool CQueue::IsValid ( ) const [inline, virtual]

Check if the object is attached to a valid FreRTOS native handle.

Returns:
true if the is attached to a valid FreRTOS native handle, false otherwise.

Implements IFreeRTOSObj.
